unnormalised: ## Plugging into the Future: EV Charging in India - It's Happening!
normalised: ## Plugging into the Future: E V Charging in India - It's Happening!

unnormalised: Hey guys! So, I've been geeking out about EVs lately, and one thing that keeps popping up is charging infrastructure. It's the elephant in the room, right? We can all dream of cruising down Marine Drive in our Tata Nexon EV, but where the heck are we going to plug it in?
normalised: Hey guys! So, I've been geeking out about E V's lately, and one thing that keeps popping up is charging infrastructure. It's the elephant in the room, right? We can all dream of cruising down Marine Drive in our Tata Nexon E V, but where the heck are we going to plug it in?

unnormalised: Well, things are actually looking up! Remember those days when finding an EV charger was like hunting for a decent plate of biryani at 3 AM? (Almost impossible, unless you knew a guy, who knew a guy...). Now, companies like Tata Power and Ather Energy are seriously ramping up their charging networks. You're starting to see charging stations popping up at malls, petrol pumps (ironic, right?), and even some apartment complexes in Bangalore and Delhi.
normalised: Well, things are actually looking up! Remember those days when finding an E V charger was like hunting for a decent plate of biryani at three A M? (Almost impossible, unless you knew a guy, who knew a guy...). Now, companies like Tata Power and Ather Energy are seriously ramping up their charging networks. You're starting to see charging stations popping up at malls, petrol pumps (ironic, right?), and even some apartment complexes in Bangalore and Delhi.

unnormalised: The government is also pushing things forward. Think subsidies and incentives to set up charging points. Plus, there's talk of mandating charging infrastructure in new construction projects. That's HUGE!
normalised: The government is also pushing things forward. Think subsidies and incentives to set up charging points. Plus, there's talk of mandating charging infrastructure in new construction projects. That's HUGE!

unnormalised: Okay, so it's not perfect. We're still a long way from the charging ubiquity you see in places like Europe. And the cost can be a bit of a pain. Public charging can range from Rs. 15-25 per unit, and installing a home charger can set you back anywhere from Rs. 10,000 to Rs. 50,000 depending on the type.
normalised: Okay, so it's not perfect. We're still a long way from the charging ubiquity you see in places like Europe. And the cost can be a bit of a pain. Public charging can range from rupees fifteen to twenty five per unit, and installing a home charger can set you back anywhere from rupees ten thousand to rupees fifty thousand depending on the type.

unnormalised: But look at the progress! Just a few years ago, driving an EV long distance felt like prepping for a mountaineering expedition. Now, with the increasing range of EVs (like the MG ZS EV doing 400+ km on a charge) and a growing charging network, road trips to places like Lonavala or even Jaipur are becoming a real possibility.
normalised: But look at the progress! Just a few years ago, driving an E V long distance felt like prepping for a mountaineering expedition. Now, with the increasing range of E V's (like the M G Z S E V doing four hundred plus kilometer on a charge) and a growing charging network, road trips to places like Lonavala or even Jaipur are becoming a real possibility.

unnormalised: This Onam, I even saw an EV charging station decked out with pookalams (flower arrangements)! That's when you know things are getting serious.
normalised: This Onam, I even saw an E V charging station decked out with pookalams (flower arrangements)! That's when you know things are getting serious.

unnormalised: So, yeah, EV charging in India still has a way to go. But the momentum is there. It's exciting to see how fast things are changing. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm off to research which charging station near my house has the shortest queue…Wish me luck!
